subject: Re: [junit] Running 1 out N testcases
msgSnippet: ... I put this in all my concrete TestCases: public static void main( String[] argv ) { if (argv.length == 0) { // run all of the tests
messageBody:
Arun wrote:
> I have a testsuite which contains multiple testcases. Is it possible
> to run a single test by passing a command-line option ?
>
> Otherwise I have to manually comment/uncomments the testcases and
> recompile the code. This is quite inefficient.

I put this in all my concrete TestCases:

public static void main( String[] argv ) {
if (argv.length == 0) {
// run all of the tests
junit.textui.TestRunner.run(suite());
} else {
// try to load and run each named test individually
for (int i = 0; i < argv.length; ++i) {
String testName = argv[i];

try {
// run the test. it throw if the test failed, but it will if the
// testName was invalid or couldn't be invoked.
junit.textui.TestRunner.run(new FooTest(testName));
} catch (Exception x) {
System.err.println(
"The test method named '" + testName + "' could not be run:
" + x);
}
}
}
}

In other words, calling the test case from the command line with no args
runs the entire TestSuite (however that's been defined); with one arg,
it runs that named test only. This is a lot to type for each TestCase
that you create, but I generate my new TestCases from a script to ease
the pain.
